node.title: Slow convergence in frictional contact
node.bodyText:
I am interested in frictional contact problem. I have create a very simple example, which should at least converge. Here is the input file for it. Problem description: a soft cube is pressed against a hard block through displacement BC at top and then moved horizontally. Penalty method is applied.
[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
  patch_update_strategy = 'iteration'
  volumetric_locking_correction = true
[]

[Mesh]
  [rectangle_body]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 3
    xmin= 20
    xmax = 50
    ymin = 6
    ymax = 36
    zmin = -15
    zmax = 15
    nx = 2
    ny = 2
    nz = 2
    elem_type = HEX
    boundary_name_prefix = 'box'
  []

  [plane_rigid]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 3
    xmin= 0
    xmax = 100
    ymin = 0
    ymax = 5
    zmin = -50
    zmax = 50
    nx = 1
    ny = 1
    nz = 1
    elem_type = HEX
    boundary_name_prefix = 'plane'
    boundary_id_offset = 6
    subdomain_ids = 1
  []

  [cmbn]
    type = CombinerGenerator
    inputs = 'rectangle_body plane_rigid'
  []

  [cmbn_new]
    type = RenameBlockGenerator
    input = cmbn
    old_block = '0 1'
    new_block = 'box plane'
  []
[]

[Variables]
    [disp_x]
    []
    [disp_y]
    []
    [disp_z]
    []
[]

[Functions]
  [ydisp]
    type = ParsedFunction
    vars = 't0   t_end  disp'
    vals = '10.0  20.0    -4'
    value = 'if (t<t0, 0.0, if (t<t_end, disp*(t-t0)/(t_end-t0), disp))'
  []
  [xdisp]
    type = ParsedFunction
    vars = 't0   t_end  disp'
    vals = '20.0  30.0    5'
    value = 'if (t<t0, 0.0, disp*(t-t0)/(t_end-t0))'
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [./norm_force_x]
  [../]
  [./norm_force_y]
  [../]  
  [./norm_force_z]
  [../]  
  [./tang_force_x]
  [../]
  [./tang_force_y]
  [../]
  [./tang_force_z]
  [../]
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [./normal_force_x]
    type = PenetrationAux
    variable = norm_force_x
    execute_on = timestep_end
    quantity = normal_force_x
    boundary = box_bottom
    paired_boundary = plane_top
  [../]
  [./normal_force_y]
    type = PenetrationAux
    variable = norm_force_y
    execute_on = timestep_end
    quantity = normal_force_y
    boundary = box_bottom
    paired_boundary = plane_top
  [../]
  [./normal_force_z]
    type = PenetrationAux
    variable = norm_force_z
    execute_on = timestep_end
    quantity = normal_force_z
    boundary = box_bottom
    paired_boundary = plane_top
  [../]
  [./tangential_force_x]
    type = PenetrationAux
    variable = tang_force_x
    execute_on = timestep_end
    quantity = tangential_force_x
    boundary = box_bottom
    paired_boundary = plane_top
  [../]
  [./tangential_force_y]
    type = PenetrationAux
    variable = tang_force_y
    execute_on = timestep_end
    quantity = tangential_force_y
    boundary = box_bottom
    paired_boundary = plane_top
  [../]
  [./tangential_force_z]
    type = PenetrationAux
    variable = tang_force_z
    execute_on = timestep_end
    quantity = tangential_force_z
    boundary = box_bottom
    paired_boundary = plane_top
  [../]
[]

[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
  [./all]
    add_variables = true
    strain = FINITE
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
  [xfixed]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = 'plane_top plane_bottom'
    value = 0
  []
  [yfixed]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = 'plane_top plane_bottom'
    value = 0
  []
  [zfixed]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = 'plane_top plane_bottom box_top'
    value = 0
  []
  [ydisp]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = box_top
    function = ydisp
    preset = 0
  []
  [xdisp]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = box_top
    function = xdisp
    preset = 0
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [strain_all]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
    block = 'box plane'
  []

  [Top]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 5
    poissons_ratio = 0.49
    block = 'box'
  []
  [Bottom]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 1e6
    poissons_ratio = 0.3
    block = 'plane'
  []

[]

[Contact]
  [contact_interface]
    primary = plane_top
    secondary = box_bottom
    formulation = penalty
    model = coulomb
    friction_coefficient = 0.4
    normalize_penalty = true
    penalty = 1e+2
    normal_smoothing_distance = 0.1
  []
[]

[Dampers]
  [contact_slip]
    type = ContactSlipDamper
    secondary = box_bottom
    primary = plane_top
    min_damping_factor = 1e-5
  []
[]
[Preconditioning]
  [SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = NEWTON
  
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu        mumps'
  line_search = contact
  automatic_scaling = false
  contact_line_search_ltol = 1e-3
  nl_max_its = 100
  l_max_its = 40
  start_time = 0.0
  dt = 1
  dtmin = 1e-5
  end_time = 30.0

  verbose = true
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-4
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-4
[] # Executioner

[Outputs]
  color = false
  [out]
    type = Exodus
  []
  [pgraph]
    type = PerfGraphOutput
    level = 6                     # Default is 1
    heaviest_branch = true        # Default is false
    heaviest_sections = 10        # Default is 0
  []
[] # Outputs

As it is a very simple problem, I would expect convergence and that too in reasonable number of newton iterations. However, the convergence is really slow, with the cumulative number of nl iterations in the range of 200+ for some values of friction coefficients, i.e. high values (>0.7) and very low values (<0.05). However, for intermediate values, it does not even converge.
Further investigation in the code of Jacobian computation, I found that the Jacobian for penalty formulation for frictionless and friction case are same. It seems that there is no contribution to the tangent matrix due to frictional contact.
\\\ in MechanicalContactConstraint::computeQpJacobian()
case ContactFormulation::PENALTY:
{
      if (pinfo->_mech_status == PenetrationInfo::MS_SLIPPING ||
          pinfo->_mech_status == PenetrationInfo::MS_SLIPPING_FRICTION)
        return _phi_secondary[_j][_qp] * penalty * _test_secondary[_i][_qp] *
               pinfo->_normal(_component) * pinfo->_normal(_component);
      else
        return _phi_secondary[_j][_qp] * penalty * _test_secondary[_i][_qp];
}

Can this be the reason for slow convergence? Can you please also provide the reference from where this formulation for Jacobian is taken?

An augmented Lagrange approach to node-face is available. You could also give that a try. But I don't think AL has been extensively used.
I am not familiar with the form of the Jacobian that was implemented for that frictional case. Maybe @bwspenc can help there.

node.title: "Truly" Global Parameters in MOOSE input file for parsed functions
node.bodyText:
Is there a way to define truly global parameters in the input file? Say I have a parameter that is included in several locations e.g used in parsed functions, is it possible to define it in one location?
In the Pasred Functions block, you need to define "symbol_names" and "symbol_values" below it with the value. In some other blocks that use parsed functions (e.g ParsedGenerateSideset, you need to define "constant_names" and "constant_expressions".
Instead of needing to specify for each block, is there a way to specify a 1 to 1 "replacement"? That is, wherever the input file sees "x0" it automatically replaces it with some value you define? This would be useful for other blocks too, say, within the executioner, you define the dtmin and dtmax at the top of the file as some kind of parameter, say "dtmin_val = 0.2", so you can write:
"dtmin = dtmin_val" in the executioner block and the input file automatically replaces it with 0.2? Even though, originally, the executioner has no "constant_values"/"constant_expressions" option.
I tried using the "GlobalParams" system but that didn't work.
The purpose for this is that I want to write a bash script to loop over several values of a parameter and run the simulation each time, but that's kinda hard to do when you have to go looking through the whole file for the various places you define the parameter.

You can define parameters at the top of the input file then refer to them in each parameter:
abc = 3

[Auxkernels]
  [p]
    type = ParsedAux
    expression = 'a + efg'
    symbol_names = 'efg'
    symbol_values = '${abc}'
[][]

for example
This is what I was looking for. Thank you.

use this
${fparse 2.2*period*tp }
perfect. thanks!

node.title: Initialization of dynamic simulations
node.bodyText:
In timeintegrator (for example CentralDifferece), if I don't explicitly specify the initial velocities, does MOOSE treat the initial velocities as zero?
I know you can set inactive_tsteps=1 to switch off the velocity and acceleration calculation at the first time step, my question is if I don't do that, what value did MOOSE assign to the initial velocities?
Variables are initialized to 0 if they are not otherwise initialized.
great, got it

node.title: 'RankTwoAux' is not a registered object
node.bodyText:
Hello
I submitted a job but there was an error like below. Do you know what's wrong with it?

Thanks
Pengfei

Hello
The RankTwoAux is in the tensor mechanics module. You need to include this module in the Makefile of the app you are using and re-compile before you can use it
Please consult the guidelines before posting:

please copy paste text instead of screenshots.
please search other threads before creating your own. This was asked last week
I did include tensor mechanics module. But it still has that error.

make clobberall
then
make -j6
again
Thank you. It's fixed.

node.title: How to pick a function type for my data
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I have data that is heat at different x points at different times to inform a boundary condition. So if I were to put it in columns it would looks like:
time x heat
0 x0 heat 1
0 x1 heat 2
0 x2 heat 3
1 x0 heat 4
1 x1 heat 5
1 x2 heat 6
At the moment I'm using a vector processor of type CSVreader to read the data and a function of type NearestReporterFunction and a BC of type FunctionDirichletBC to use the funnction. It isn't working and the error is "No valid AXIS lines found by GriddedData"
Any ideas on how I can fix this either changing the data structure or the input file?
Thanks in advnace

Hello
For data depending on time and a spatial position, we can also use either of these two
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/functions/PiecewiseMulticonstant.html
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/functions/PiecewiseMultilinear.html
They will require some modification to the data structure to add some of these AXIS X Y Z T columns
I m puzzled by your error
No valid AXIS lines found by GriddedData is returned by GriddedData which is used by the functions I linked to but not by any of the objects you mention.
Are you sure it doesnt come from some extraneous object in your input file?
also what is NearestReporterFunction? I see a NearestReporterCoordinatesFunction in the optimization module
Guillaume

node.title: Mesh Refinement for nuclei insertion in phase field mode;

node.bodyText:
Hi, thanks for your question. If you are inserting all the nuclei at the same time, I don't think there is a good reason to use the nucleation system. Can't you just add them in the initial conditions for your simulation?
Maybe you are doing this because need to simulate the evolution of your system for some time prior to the instantaneous nucleation event? Even if you need to do this, there is probably a better way than using the nucleation system. For example you could run one simulation for pre-nucleation, then start another simulation where you read in all the other necessary fields from the pre-nucleation simulation (i.e. concentrations) using a SolutionUserObject, and initialize the order parameter field with all the nuclei you want. SolutionUserObject documentation is below, with links to other necessary objects and examples.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/userobjects/SolutionUserObject.html
Also be aware that no matter what you do, you are going to need to use an adequate number of elements to properly resolve each nucleus. Probably at an absolute minimum 3 elements across the interface and 5-7 across the interior of the nucleus. This is an inherent limitation of the phase-field method. So there isn't really a way to add a bunch of nuclei in to your system without also adding the mesh elements necessary to resolve them adequately.

So if my system is 100 um x 100 um and I am going to place a 0.1 um nuclei as a initial condition. Will I need around 5000 x 5000 mesh elements. That is computationally very expensive. Can't I have non uniform mesh elements being concentrated only at the nuclei ? Can I execute this using the targeted mesh refinement prior to nucleus insertion.

no you wont. @laagesen gave you criteria near and inside the nucleus, not everywhere else.
MOOSE can handle non-uniform meshes, it can perform adaptive mesh refinement (AMR), and it can generate non-uniform meshes (this one for example: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/CartesianMeshGenerator.html)
I think you may find in the phase field modules examples of resolving a nucleaus using AMR

Thanks for the reply. Can you suggest some mesh generator in which I can refine mesh along y-axis at a specific interval in x only. The CartesianMeshGenerator is refining the mesh along y-axis independently from the x-axis as per my understanding.
My system requires x intervals as 18 4 78 (xmax = 100)
with grids ix 18 40 78 (concentrated grids for the 4 interval)
But now I will require y grids for x=18 interval as iy=100 (my is ymax=100)
x= 4 interval as iy= 400 (concentrated grids along y)
x= 78 interval as iy =100
Thank you

CMG is usually good but I can see how that doesnt work for you here.
Ok so let's do a regular or near regular grid in the CMG
then
a SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator around the nucleus location
then
a RefineBlockGenerator on the new block, which will locally increase the mesh density

Before you do anything with large meshes, I would suggest running a simple 2-nucleus problem to make sure all your model parameters are settings are correct if you haven't already done so. Create 2 particles with one smaller than the other using a uniform mesh fine enough to resolve the interface, and verify that you have about 3 elements through the interface throughout the simulation, and that the small particle coarsens away and transfers its mass to the larger one. This is will allow you identify any issues prior to spending a lot of time waiting for larger simulations to run.
For a phase-field simulation, I'd recommend using the adaptivity system and letting it choose where to refine the mesh, rather than relying on specifying using a SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator and RefineBlockGenerator - the issue is that as the microstructure changes, the initial nuclei will coarsen, so the positions where you need a finer mesh may change.
I'd recommending creating the mesh using a GeneratedMesh generator and using the adaptivity system to refine where needed. You can see an example of adaptivity using a two-order parameter model
/Users/aagelk/projects/moose/modules/phase_field/examples/anisotropic_interfaces/GrandPotentialPlanarGrowth.i
Please have a look at the documentation for the adaptivity system here:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Adaptivity/

node.title: Shape functions in FV Elemental Kernel
node.bodyText:
Hi,
How can I access shape functions _phi[_j] and _grad_phi[_j] in an FV elemental kernel?

Hello
I dont think you can, they're both unnecessary at this point in time where we only do constant monomial FV variable.
grad is 0, phi is constant.
what are you planning to do?
Guillaume

Oh right. I was thinking of an approximation to the functional derivative of an energy term that has the square of the gradient. That is a term that leads to a flux kernel in FV and if I could replace the functional derivative with terms that only has first-order derivatives and lead to Elemental terms, I could see what the difference in timing is. There is a "Box" approximation for that functional derivative (used in the old Magpar code) but the price is a gradient of the shape function. But I'll drop that thought.

See my comment on the other thread.
Are you coding the weak form in FV?
We can do variable.gradient(elem_arg) to get an elemental gradient btw
I am doing strong form of FV. Yes I've seen (and used) the elemental gradient form. I have to think a little bit more about how to use the "Box" approximation sensibly.

node.title: Articial Viscosity / Diffusion based stabilisation
node.bodyText:
Hi All
I am modelling a problem in MOOSE that involves solving a hyperbolic PDE. I have been having good success at stabilizing the solution by adding an artificial diffusion / viscosity term $\nu \Delta u$. Currently, I am applying this indiscriminately to the whole domain but I want to make this method more refined. Specifically, I want the viscosity term to be a function of the residual ie:

where the residual for the 1d transport eq would be $r(x)=u_t(x)+u_x(x)$. I am unsure how best to implement this in MOOSE, should I just calculate $r(x)$ directly or can I use the tagging system?
Many Thanks
Jake

Hello
I would calculate r directly.
We don’t compute the residual in two steps so on paper we would not have access to the residual when computing a term of the residual.
However,
You could either:

try to use a projection of the previous residual by tagging it then copying it at the end of a time step in an aux variable. That might not be great
Using the show_exeucution_order Boolean option in the Debug block you could make sure this kernel is calculated last. This is iffy but could work. There s no réal guarantee on the order of execution of kernels


Guillaume

Thank @GiudGiud, I will proceed with calculating r directly. Is there a way to access old values of $\nabla u$ like there is for $\dot{u}$ (_var.uDotOld())?
Edit: believe I can use _var.gradSlnOld()

you can use this too:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/moose/classCoupleable.html#aafe7b956f1dbe65960e5b6620f6a1236
It relies on the coupleable interface, which requires you to add your variable in the coupled variable parameters and also initialize a member variable of the class with coupledGradientOld

In the Navier Stokes SUPG implementation we compute strong form residuals in materials and reuse those in 1) terms that are not integrated by parts and 2) the kernel that adds the SUPG stabilization. Perhaps you could consider a similar design

node.title: compiling issues
node.bodyText:
I can compile my application previously and didn't face a problem, but this time I just got this error
(moose) [zchen@mercury army_ants]$ make -j 6
Creating Unity Directory /data/zchen/projects/army_ants/build/unity_src
Creating Unity /data/zchen/projects/army_ants/build/unity_src/kernels_Unity.C
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /data/zchen/projects/army_ants/build/unity_src/kernels_Unity.C...
Linking Library /data/zchen/projects/army_ants/lib/libarmy_ants-opt.la...
Linking Executable /data/zchen/projects/army_ants/army_ants-opt...
/data/zchen/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/10.4.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /data/zchen/projects/army_ants/lib/libarmy_ants-opt.so: undefined reference to `InputParameters validParams<Diffusion>()'
/data/zchen/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/10.4.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /data/zchen/projects/army_ants/lib/libarmy_ants-opt.so: undefined reference to `InputParameters validParams<Kernel>()'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
make: *** [/data/zchen/projects/moose/framework/app.mk:445: /data/zchen/projects/army_ants/army_ants-opt] Error 1

Hello
This seems to a refer to a very old deprecation (2 years ago). Do you have templated validParams method declarations in your headers?
Is army_ants an application? How old is it? Can you please paste the header for one of its Diffusion kernel here?
Guillaume

TempDiffusion.h.tar.gz
hi this is the header of the temp diffusion.

yeah this is exactly what I was talking about
see the page I linked on the other post
template<>
InputParameters validParams<TempDiffusion>();

this is totally deprecated and removed syntax

node.title: Error using mpiexec
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I wrote a coupled THM code using MOOSE and it works fine on a single core, but when I want to run it in multicore using "mpiexec", I get this error:
mpiexec -n 4 ./frozen_soil_thm -i ./problems/THMTests4_coupled_verification/input.i
[proxy:0:0@Kians-MacBook-Air.local] HYDU_create_process (utils/launch/launch.c:73): execvp error on file ./frozen_soil_thm (No such file or directory)
[proxy:0:0@Kians-MacBook-Air.local] HYDU_create_process (utils/launch/launch.c:73): execvp error on file ./frozen_soil_thm (No such file or directory)
[proxy:0:0@Kians-MacBook-Air.local] HYDU_create_process (utils/launch/launch.c:73): execvp error on file ./frozen_soil_thm (No such file or directory)
[proxy:0:0@Kians-MacBook-Air.local] HYDU_create_process (utils/launch/launch.c:73): execvp error on file ./frozen_soil_thm (No such file or directory)
This is a THM code and it wasn't an issue before adding the mechanical codes (when it was just a TH code) but now I'm getting this.
I would appreciate it if you could let me know what the problem might be.
Thanks.

You're getting this error because frozen_soil_thm does not exist. It shouldn't work in serial without mpi either.
Make sure you're in the right directory and make sure your application is compiled.
Thank you. Yes, it was a silly mistake!
